title: R44053
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, comparing enacted FY2015 appropriations, the Administration's FY2016 budget request, Congress's proposed appropriations, and those enacted so far. It includes additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for inquiries. The suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations tracks legislative action and congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts. The curr_chunk discusses the appropriations legislation for DHS programs, explaining budgetary concepts such as budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, and adjustments to spending caps. For a more detailed explanation, readers are referred to additional resources like CRS Report R42388 and the Government Accountability Office's glossary of budget terms. The amounts in CRS reports on homeland security appropriations represent specific funding details. The CRS reports on homeland security appropriations provide budget authority amounts rounded to the nearest million. Calculations use unrounded data for precision in percentages and totals. Data sources include the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, FY2015, and congressional documentation for FY2016. The FY2016 budget request and Senate-reported funding levels are from S. 1619 and S.Rept. 114-68, while the House-reported funding levels are from H.R. 3128 and H.Rept. 114-215. Data for FY2016 are derived from P.L. 114-113, the Omnibus Appropriations Act, 2016. The homeland security appropriations bill allocates resources to all DHS components, with discretionary appropriations providing the majority of funding for DHS operations. The DHS budget includes fee revenues, trust funds, and mandatory spending. Appropriations for DHS are typically organized into five titles, with Title I focusing on Departmental Management and Operations. The FY2016 budget request for this title was $1,396 million, an increase of $255 million from FY2015. Senate-reported funding levels envisioned $1,346 million for components in this title. The FY2016 budget for the Department of Homeland Security included $1,346 million in net discretionary budget authority, which was $50 million less than requested but $205 million more than in FY2015. Title II, Security, Enforcement, and Investigations, received $1,546 million in net discretionary budget authority, a $150 million increase from the request and $405 million above FY2015. This title covers appropriations for Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Transportation Security Administration, Coast Guard, and Secret Service. The Administration requested $32,481 million in FY2016 net discretionary budget authority for components included in this title, as part of a total budget for these components of $39,431 million for FY2016. The appropriations request was $807 million (2.5%) more than was provided for FY2015. Senate-reported S. 1619 envisioned the components included in this title receiving $32,484 million in net discretionary budget authority, $3 million (0.01%) more than requested, and $810 million (2.6%) more than was provided in FY2015. House-reported H.R. 3128 envisioned the components included in this title receiving $32,182 million in net discretionary budget authority, $299 million (0.9%) less than requested, and $508 million (1.6%) more than was provided in FY2015. Division F of P.L. 114-113 included $33,062 million in net discretionary budget authority for the components in this title. Title III, Protection, Preparedness, Response, and Recovery, includes $33,062 million in net discretionary budget authority, a $581 million increase from the request and $1,388 million above FY2015. The Administration requested $6,222 million for FY2016, $267 million more than FY2015. Senate-reported S. 1619 proposed $6,291 million, $69 million more than requested. Title IV, Research and Development, Training, and Services, includes appropriations for USCIS, FLETC, S&T, and DNDO. The requested FY2016 budget authority was $1,554 million. This is part of the overall budget increase from FY2015. The Administration requested $1,554 million in FY2016 net discretionary budget authority for components in Title IV, which was part of a total budget of $5,427 million. The appropriations request was $251 million less than FY2015. Senate-reported S. 1619 proposed $1,451 million, $103 million less than requested. House-reported H.R. 3128 proposed $1,503 million, $51 million less than requested. Division F of P.L. 114-113 included $1,499 million, a $55 million decrease from the request. The Administration proposed rescinding $255 million in prior-year appropriations as part of its FY2016 budget request. Senate-reported S. 1619 included $1,359 million in rescissions, while House-reported H.R. 3128 included $1,692 million. Division F of P.L. 114-113 included $1,506 million in rescissions. The tables present comparisons of FY2015 enacted and FY2016 requested, House and Senate appropriations committee-reported, and enacted appropriations for the department by thematic grouping. The tables summarize appropriations provided for each component in the FY2016 appropriations cycle, indicating resources from various sources for the fiscal year. Subtotals are provided for each component, along with totals for individual titles and components in the entire bill. Total FY2016 funding for DHS components from all sources, outside of the defense budget function, competes for discretionary spending allocations under the Budget Control Act. House Homeland Security Subcommittee Chairman John Carter expressed concern over the proposed $1.5 billion increase for DHS, which absorbs a significant portion of non-defense discretionary spending. Congress aims to adhere to budget constraints despite the Administration's budget request. The Administration proposed a 1.3% pay increase for civilian federal employees and military members in its FY2016 budget request. DHS employees, mostly civilians, may not see a steep rise in their budget as the Senate and House Appropriations Committees suggest absorbing the cost within existing funds. Military pay raise was fully funded according to the House Appropriations Committee report. The military pay raise was fully funded, and an executive order authorized a 1.3% pay adjustment for federal civilian employees in January 2016. The FY2016 Homeland Security Appropriations Act included a provision prohibiting structural pay reform affecting more than 100 positions or costing over $5 million until Congress is notified. The Senate Appropriations Committee report highlighted hiring difficulties at the Department of Homeland Security, with delays in bringing funded positions on board due to various reasons. Hiring times have increased department-wide and at Customs and Border Protection, leading to challenges in recruitment and retention of qualified applicants. The U.S. Secret Service, however, improved its hiring times according to the committee report. The Senate Appropriations Committee report highlighted hiring challenges at the Department of Homeland Security, with delays in bringing funded positions on board. Despite improvements in hiring times at the U.S. Secret Service, the hiring process still takes a long time. The report directed DHS to develop strategies to reduce hiring times and track hiring actions with metrics. Chronic personnel shortages and lengthy hiring times are jeopardizing DHS's homeland security mission. The DHS is facing hiring challenges and is expected to be significantly understaffed by the end of FY2015. The House report expresses doubts about DHS's ability to spend the requested funds for FY2016 and reduces funding accordingly. The report mandates the USM to analyze attrition and hiring issues, develop a corrective action plan, and provide monthly updates to the committee. Additionally, DHS is directed to report on a strategy for reducing hiring times. The committee directed DHS to provide a report on reducing hiring times and metrics, including a root cause analysis and corrective action plan. Monthly reports on hiring metrics were mandated to begin in January 2016. Outside the appropriations process, DHS was granted special authority to expedite hiring of cybersecurity professionals. The Senate and House Appropriations Committees are concerned about the Department of Homeland Security's lack of a consistent methodology for determining personnel requirements and costs. They are requesting reports and briefings on balancing technology needs with manpower costs to support DHS operations. The committee directed the OCFO to provide quarterly briefings on the progress of a force structure analysis for the FY2018 budget request. DHS components have funding limitations for reception and representation expenses, ranging from $2,000 to $34,425. The Senate and House-reported bills include limitations on reception and representation expenses totaling $177,505 and $166,955 respectively. The Senate Appropriations Committee requires quarterly reports on obligations and prohibits the purchase of unnecessary items. The House committee directs a review of representation allowances for all DHS agencies. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2016, allocated $169,655 for official reception and representation expenses. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2016 allocated $169,655 for official reception and representation expenses. The CRS analysts and specialists contribute to DHS appropriations reports, detailing budget authority, obligations, and outlays in federal government spending. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation, determining the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted budget authority. Budget authority may be indefinite, with Congress enacting language providing "such sums as may be necessary." Budget authority can be one-year, multiyear, or no-year, with obligations incurred when federal agencies engage in transactions. Outlays are the funds spent during the fiscal year, and budget authority may not always match outlays due to multiyear or no-year obligations. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. Discretionary and mandatory spending make up the total funds available for spending, with discretionary spending appropriated yearly by Congress. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, is not subject to annual appropriations acts. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, consists of budget authority and resulting outlays provided in laws other than appropriations acts. Some mandatory entitlement programs must be appropriated each year. Within DHS, Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offsetting collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of a business-type transaction and are not considered federal revenue. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts, funded by permanent or annual appropriations. Additionally, there are offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds in the DHS budget. The DHS budget includes offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds, which are not appropriated by Congress but are available for obligation. The budget authority for annual appropriations, including DHS, is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process involving 302(a) and 302(b) allocations. Congress sets overall spending totals in the annual concurrent resolution on the budget, which are then allocated among appropriations committees for enactment in annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees allocate 302(a) discretionary funds among subcommittees for appropriations bills, known as 302(b) allocations. These allocations enforce budget discipline and may be adjusted during the year. No subcommittee allocations are developed for conference reports or enacted appropriations bills. Table A-1 shows comparable figures for the 302(b) allocation for FY2015. The President's request for FY2016 Homeland Security appropriations, House and Senate subcommittee allocations, and Budget Control Act discretionary spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013 were discussed. The overall cap for FY2015 discretionary spending is $1,014 billion, with separate limits for defense and nondefense spending. Most of the DHS budget falls under nondefense. The DHS budget for FY2016 is $521 billion for nondefense spending, with adjustments allowed under the Budget Control Act for overseas contingency operations, emergency spending, and disaster relief. Adjustments for disaster relief are limited and determined by OMB. The OMB determines the allowable adjustment for disaster relief based on a formula using a rolling average of spending over the last ten fiscal years. For FY2014, the allowable adjustment was $12,143 million, with only $5,717 million exercised. In FY2015, the allowable adjustment was $18,430 million, with $11,913 million from the rolling average and $6,517 million carried over from FY2014. FY2016 had an allowable adjustment of $14,125 million.
